rough the North Channel LEPC, as well as the Harris County Office of Emergency Management. The site is also a participating member of the Houston Ship Channel Area Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).  The site has a severe weather plan to prepare and recover from hurricanes, severe storms/tornadoes and flooding.

6.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
The following is a list of improvements planned to be implemented at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:
- Continued review and upgrade of safety interlocks system.
- Revalidate all PHAs in accordance with requirements under RMP and PSM.
- Continue incorporating BLEVE Analysis into PHAs.  This effort began with PHAs conducted in 4th Quarter 2020.
- Evaluate and where necessary, update facility siting requirements for the site.
- Revise the emergency response plan after critiques from recent drills.
- Develop and coordinate new notification, field and tabletop emergency response exercises per regulatory timelines.
- Update facility security following a Security and Vulnerability Survey.  
- Continue to utilize the facility’s formal incident investigation process to investigate incidents and develop effective solutions to prevent recurrence.

e provisions set forth under the PSM and RMP rules are being implemented. These audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years.

Employee Participation:  The site has a written employee participation plan that defines how employees are consulted in the development and maintenance of the PSM/RMP elements.  Employees participate in PHA’s, and they have access to the PHA’s and other process safety information.  Each operating and maintenance area has a representative on the Plant Safety Committee (EAGLES - Eliminating Accidents Guarantees Lasting Employee Safety) which supports occupational safety activities.  Contractors have a representative on this team.

Contractor Safety Program: The plant has a program to ensure that contractors are properly trained and uses the Houston Area Safety Council as a tool to provide the basic HSE training required of a contractor prior to entering a chemical manufacturing facility. All contractor employees must attend the Houston Area Safety Council training and be certified through examination prior to arriving at the plant. In addition to basic training, site specific training is required prior to arriving at the plant. The company has a rigorous process for pre-screening all contract companies to ensure they meet all company requirements.  All resident and many non-resident contractors are part of the site’s CHESS (Contractors Helping Everyone Stay Safe) Team.

4.0 Five Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases of substances regulated under the RMP rule at this facility over the last 5 years.

5.0 Emergency Response
The site maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. This program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the site coordinates with the community response plan th

pment are in place to ensure it operates safely.  Plant and unit specific procedures for servicing operating equipment are in place, including preventative / predictive maintenance and reliability programs.

Maintenance Training: Mechanics and other craftsmen who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks are trained and tested on process equipment and inspections on operating equipment to ensure they have the required knowledge and skills.

Mechanical Integrity Program: Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are periodically tested and inspected to ensure safe operations, following recognized standards and governmental requirements.  Due to the size of the facility, inspections are conducted on some portion of the equipment a daily basis.

Quality Assurance: A system is in place to ensure that purchased equipment and materials meet established engineering standards and specifications. 

Management of Change: The site has a management system to ensure that modifications to a process or facilities are evaluated for impact to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures and/or facilities. Evaluation and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are conducted prior to implementation of the change.  The site also has a Management of Organizational Change procedure to address the safety and health impacts of organizational changes when those changes impact technology, equipment, procedures and/or facilities.  

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs): Reviews are conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities or processes are safe to operate.  

Incident Investigation: The site has an established program to formally investigate accidents and serious near misses to determine causes and corrective/preventative actions.  These causes and actions are documented and tracked to completion, and learning opportunities are identified and communicated site wide.

Compliance Audits:  Audits are conducted on a regular basis to verify th

ll Chemicals Channelview Operations (CVOS) has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68. Additionally, this facility was designed and constructed in accordance with strict internal engineering standards and is subject to the requirements under 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management.

Process Safety Information: Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, kept up-to-date, and made available to all workers.  

Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs): A rigorous practice of reviewing new processes or changes to existing processes at the design stage is utilized, with the overall thought of identifying and mitigating health, safety and environmental issues before installation or operation. Scheduled PHAs are conducted every 5 years to revalidate previous hazard reviews, incorporate new Corporate requirements and learnings from incidents.  Corrective actions are recommended and tracked to prevent accidents.

Operating Procedures: Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are kept up-to-date constantly thru a review during any operator training opportunity.  They are also reviewed every five years.  Operating procedures are based on process hazard / risk reviews and are periodically modified as a result of management of change activities or after completion of a process PHA.  These procedures also specifically identify steps/responses that are taken as administrative independent protective layers. Operating procedures include safe start-up and emergency shutdown of a process unit.

Operator Training / Qualification Program: A training and testing program is in place to ensure that operators have the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.  Operator re-qualification is required at a minimum of every three years.  

Maintenance Procedures:  Specific procedures for maintaining process equi

icals that have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of their substantial accidental release:

Toxics - 

Propylene Oxide (PO): Approximately 97 million lbs. are on-site based on storage, production and use. PO is the major product of the CVOS facility and is also a feedstock for the Polyols and BDO production units.

Allyl Alcohol (AA): Approximately 7.5 million lbs. are on-site based on storage and production. AA is a product produced in the BDO unit.

Ethylene Oxide (EO): Approximately 4.6 million lbs. are stored and used on-site. EO is a primary feedstock of the Polyols unit.

Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3): Approximately 120,000 lbs. of NH3 are stored on-site to be utilized in the control of Nitrogen Oxides (NOX) in the Utilities area.

Flammables - 

Propylene: Approximately 1.6 million lbs. are stored and used on-site. Propylene is the primary feedstock for both PO units and the POTBA unit.

Ethylene: Approximately 39,000 lbs. are contained in a pipeline and is used as a primary feedstock to produce Ethylbenzene in the two PO/SM units.

Isobutylene: Approximately 9.2 million lbs. are stored in a sphere, railcars and within the process of the RTBE unit. Isobutylene is an intermediate chemical used in the production of RTBE and is purified for selling as finished product.

Flammable Mixtures:  Approximately 36 million lbs. of flammable mixtures are stored and processed through-out the PO/SM, POTBA, BDO, and RTBE units and (un)loading areas.  Regulated substances in these flammable mixtures are:  Acetaldehyde, Butane, Isobutane, Isobutylene, Methylamine, Propane, Propylene and Propylene oxide. 

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

3.0 General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Lyonde

Lyondell Chemical Company
Channelview Operations (CVOS)
2502 Sheldon Road
Channelview, TX 77530

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary 8/12/2022

1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Lyondell Channelview Plant (CVOS) is committed to operating and maintaining our processes to protect our employees, the public, and the environment. We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to manage the risk for all stakeholders. This document provides a brief overview of our comprehensive risk management activities to prevent and mitigate the possibility of an accidental release of a regulated chemical.

It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent the release of a regulated substance.  However, if such a release does occur, our trained emergency response   personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of any release. We also coordinate with the Houston Ship Channel Area’s Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) organization, which provides additional emergency response expertise.

The plan has been updated to include a new Propylene Oxide/Tertiary Butyl Alcohol (POTBA) unit that will begin commissioning in late August 2022.  Therefore, this submittal includes predictive filing.  As part of the overall review of the re-submission, the regulated substances and inventories were reviewed, and updates have been made accordingly.  

2.0 Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Our facility produces a number of products that include Propylene Oxide (PO), Styrene Monomer (SM), Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE), Ethyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (ETBE), Polyether Polyols (Polyols), Tertiary Butyl Alcohol, and various products from the Butanediols (BDO) unit, including Allyl Alcohol (AA). There are two PO/SM units, one POTBA unit, one “RTBE” unit in which either MTBE or ETBE can be produced, one Polyols unit, and one BDO unit. These operating units process the following chem
